Article Title: 'Lolita', Bill Gates and passports: New Epstein photos released ‚Äî what they reveal
Article Text:

After Donald Trump , several other celebrities have now become the new target of the House Oversight Committee as Democrats released new photos from Jeffrey Epstein ‚Äôs estate on Thursday, on the eve of the Department of Justice‚Äôs deadline to release all of its files on his case.The Committee released around 70 photographs, drawn from Epstein‚Äôs computer and email accounts, there were among 95,000 handed over by Epstein‚Äôs estate last week and were provided to the committee without context. They shed further light on his lifestyle and social circles.One image shows former Microsoft CEO Bill Gates standing next to a woman whose face is redacted. Another features Noam Chomsky seated beside Epstein on a plane.Several photographs depict a social gathering over a meal and include faces of powerful or public figures, among them Epstein. A separate image, apparently from the same room, shows Google co-founder Sergey Brin beside New York Times columnist David Brooks.A New York Times spokesperson said in a statement, ‚ÄúAs a journalist, David Brooks regularly attends events to speak with noted and important business leaders to inform his columns, which is exactly what happened at this 2011 event.Mr. Brooks had no contact with him before or after this single attendance at a widely-attended dinner.‚ÄùSeveral images in the new release show Epstein with women whose faces have been redacted. One photograph appears to show three women with Epstein beside an open computer, one of the women with her arm around his shoulder. Another shows Epstein seated on a plane, pointing out a window while a woman sits closely beside him; her face has also been obscured.Some photos in this batch offer close-ups of a foot and a neck, both inscribed in black pen with quotes from the book Lolita.Additional items include identification cards or passports of several unidentified people from countries such as Russia and the Czech Republic, a hand holding open Epstein‚Äôs own passport, and what appears to be a screenshot of text messages saying "I will send u girls now",‚Äù with another one showing an unknown sender writing, ‚ÄúMaybe someone would be good for J?‚Äù and including the age and body measurements for an unidentified person. There is also a hand holding a drug bottle labelled for phenazopyridine, a generic analgesia used to relieve urinary tract pain and burning.The latest cache of photographs comes a day before the Justice Department‚Äôs deadline to release the Epstein files, after Congress mandated the information be made public.Rep. Robert Garcia, Democratic ranking member on the House Oversight Committee, said in a statement Thursday, ‚ÄúOversight Democrats will continue to release photographs and documents from the Epstein estate to provide transparency for the American people.‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúAs we approach the deadline for the Epstein Files Transparency Act, these new images raise more questions about what exactly the Department of Justice has in its possession. We must end this White House cover-up, and the DOJ must release the Epstein files now.‚Äù
Article Summary: House Oversight Committee releases new photos from Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs estate. One image shows former Microsoft CEO Bill Gates standing next to a woman whose face is redacted. Another features Noam Chomsky seated beside Epstein on a plane. Several photographs depict a social gathering over a meal and include faces of powerful or public figures, among them Epstein.

Article Title: Day of Reflection: Australia to take 'moment to pause and reflect'; Sunday to mark one week of Bondi Beach mass shooting
Article Text:
File photo: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese (Picture credit: AP)

Sydney: Terrifying New Video Shows Aussie Couple Confronting Bondi Gunmen; Watch What Happened Next





Australia will observe a national day of reflection on Sunday (December 21), one week after the deadly Bondi Beach mass shooting that killed 15 people, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announced on Friday, as he urged the country to reject ‚Äúhatred and violence‚Äù.Albanese called on Australians to light candles at 6:47 pm local time, marking the exact moment the attack unfolded.‚ÄúIt is a moment to pause, reflect, and affirm that hatred and violence will never define who we are as Australians,‚Äù he said.Flags on New South Wales and Australian government buildings will be flown at half-staff, reported CNN.The attack, described as Australia‚Äôs worst mass shooting in nearly three decades, took place on Sunday evening during a beachside Hanukkah celebration.Authorities have said the assault was antisemitic in nature. Sajid Akram, 50, and his son Naveed, 24, are accused of carrying out the shooting. Sajid was killed in a gunfight with police, while Naveed survived and has been charged with 15 counts of murder, an act of terrorism, and multiple other offences, according to news agency AFP.Albanese said there was ‚Äúsomething wrong with the licensing laws‚Äù that allowed Sajid Akram to legally own six long-barrelled, high-powered rifles.He announced a sweeping national gun buy-back scheme aimed at removing newly banned and illegal firearms from private ownership, reported CNN.Calling it the biggest gun buy-back since 1996, Albanese said hundreds of thousands of weapons were expected to be collected and destroyed. States and territories will handle collection and payments, while federal police will destroy the firearms.The prime minister also pledged tougher measures to combat antisemitism, including new powers to target extremist preachers and to cancel or refuse visas for people who spread hate and division. ‚ÄúIt is clear we need to do more to combat this evil scourge,‚Äù Albanese said.Emotional scenes played out at Bondi Beach on Friday as hundreds of locals swam into the ocean in a show of solidarity. ‚ÄúThey slaughtered innocent victims‚Ä¶ and being part of my community again brings back the light,‚Äù security consultant Jason Carr said, as per AFP.Others described the gathering as carrying a ‚Äúbeautiful energy‚Äù amid grief and anger.Meanwhile, Sydney remains on high alert. Police said they detained two carloads of men following a tip-off about a possible ‚Äúviolent act‚Äù, though no direct link to the Bondi attack has been established.Authorities are also investigating whether the accused were inspired by the Islamic State group, with Albanese saying intelligence agencies had identified online ISIS-linked material reinforcing that assessment.
Article Summary: Australia will observe a national day of reflection on Sunday (December 21) One week after the deadly Bondi Beach mass shooting that killed 15 people. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese urged the country to reject ‚Äúhatred and violence‚Äù He announced a sweeping national gun buy-back scheme aimed at removing newly banned and illegal firearms from private ownership.

Article Title: UAE weather alert: Heavy rain, thunder, and hail to sweep across the Emirates
Article Text:

The United Arab Emirates is currently in the grip of a notable weather disturbance that is bringing rainfall, strong winds, cooler temperatures and rough seas across much of the country. The National Centre of Meteorology (NCM) has been issuing regular forecasts and alerts as this system moves through, affecting daily life from road conditions to marine safety.Forecasters describe the situation as unstable weather, with convective cloud formations driving intermittent to heavy rain, moderate to strong winds and variable skies, from partly cloudy to overcast. Residents from Fujairah to Abu Dhabi should expect these conditions to persist through at least Friday, with a gradual easing anticipated over the weekend.The "main rainfall wave" is expected to reach its height between Thursday, December 18, and Friday, December 19. The NCM reports that the system began in the western regions and is gradually moving eastward.Authorities confirm that this instability is driven by a deep low-pressure system moving from the Red Sea, colliding with a cold air mass in the upper atmosphere.With visibility expected to drop significantly due to blowing dust and heavy rain, Dubai and Abu Dhabi Police have issued urgent safety warnings. Beyond the physical danger of wet roads, motorists face stiff penalties for reckless behavior. Officials have highlighted several "non-negotiable" rules to keep the public safe:The unsettled weather coincides with a historic milestone for Dubai International Airport (DXB), which is expecting a record-breaking 8.7 million passengers this month.Travelers are being urged to head to the airport much earlier than usual to avoid road delays on major highways like the E11 and E311. While flight operations are generally resilient, heavy thunderstorms could lead to minor schedule adjustments or gate holds.At sea, the situation is even more precarious. The NCM has issued a "rough to very rough" warning for the Arabian Gulf and the Sea of Oman. Winds are expected to gust up to 65 km/h, whipping up sand and causing waves to swell. Marine enthusiasts and boat owners are strictly advised to stay on shore until conditions stabilize.As the rain clouds begin to clear toward the end of the weekend, a noticeable chill will settle over the Emirates. Temperatures are set to drop steadily, with daytime highs falling to 24¬∞C in Dubai and 23¬∞C in Abu Dhabi. The inland city of Al Ain could see the mercury dip as low as 21¬∞C during the day and a crisp 10¬∞C at night.By Saturday evening, the heavy downpours are expected to subside, leaving only scattered clouds over northern and eastern areas. Sunday will bring a much quieter end to the week, though rising humidity could lead to misty mornings in western regions.

Article Title: Benjamin Netanyahu approves a $35 billion natural gas export deal to Egypt, biggest in Israeli history
Article Text:
FILE - An oil platform is seen in the Leviathan natural gas field on Jan. 31, 2019, in the Mediterranean Sea off Israel's coast. (Marc Israel Sellem/Pool via AP, File)

JERUSALEM: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Wednesday that he has approved a $35 billion natural gas export deal to Egypt, the biggest gas deal in Israeli history. The agreement could also help repair relations between the two countries strained during the two-year war in the Gaza Strip.The gas will be delivered to Egypt over the next 15 years by U.S. energy giant Chevron, a key owner of the gas field off Israel's coast in the Mediterranean Sea. Half of the proceeds are expected to go to Israel's state coffers.In a recorded video statement, Netanyahu said the deal "greatly strengthens Israel's position as a regional energy power, and it contributes to stability in our region."Egypt, which borders both Israel and Gaza, has served as a key mediator between Israel and the Palestinian militant Hamas group leading up to the U.S.-brokered ceasefire that was agreed on in October. Cairo has also has been a vocal critic of Israel's offensive, which has killed tens of thousands of Palestinians and caused widespread destruction in Gaza.Egypt did not immediately confirm Netanyahu's announcement.Israeli Energy Minister Eli Cohen, a close Netanyahu ally, previously held up the deal with Egypt, claiming the terms were not favorable to Israel. His delays prompted U.S. Energy Secretary Chris Wright to cancel a trip to Israel in October.But Cohen stood alongside Netanyahu during the Wednesday evening announcement and said he supported the final terms of the deal.Israel discovered sizeable natural gas fields off its Mediterranean coast in the early 2000s and began exporting gas - first to Jordan and later to Egypt - nearly a decade ago.In a separate development, German lawmakers approved an expansion of a defense agreement for Israel's sophisticated Arrow 3 missile defense system, Israel's defense ministry said Wednesday.The expansion brings the value of the deal from $3.5 billion to $6.5 billion, making it the largest Israeli defense export deal ever, according to the ministry. Germany moved to buy Arrow 3 from Israel as it seeks to strengthen its air defenses against Russia.
Article Summary: The gas will be delivered to Egypt over the next 15 years by U.S. energy giant Chevron. Half of the proceeds are expected to go to Israel's state coffers. The agreement could also help repair relations between the two countries strained during the two-year war in the Gaza Strip.

Article Title: Peace prize to Venezuela's Machado: Why is WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange suing Nobel panel? Criminal complaint filed
Article Text:
Photo credit: AP

‚ÄòVulgar Act Of Piracy‚Äô: Venezuela Slams Trump‚Äôs Total Naval Blockade, Warns Global Energy Crisis





WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has filed a criminal complaint in Sweden accusing senior figures linked to the Nobel Foundation of serious economic crimes and of facilitating war crimes, following the award of the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize to Venezuelan opposition leader Mar√≠a Corina Machado The complaint, submitted to Sweden‚Äôs Economic Crime Authority (Ekobrottsmyndigheten) and the War Crimes Unit (Krigsbrottsenheten), names around 30 individuals, including Nobel Foundation chair Astrid S√∂derbergh Widding and executive director Hanna Stj√§rne. Assange alleges breach of trust, gross misappropriation of funds, conspiracy, and the facilitation of war crimes and crimes against humanity.In a statement shared by WikiLeaks on X, the organisation said Assange‚Äôs legal action is aimed at preventing the release of more than $1 million that Machado is set to receive as part of the award. The filing seeks an immediate freeze on the pending SEK 11 million ($1.18 million) prize transfer and calls for a full criminal investigation.The complaint cites Alfred Nobel‚Äôs 1895 will, which stipulates that the Peace Prize be granted only to individuals who have ‚Äúconferred the greatest benefit to humankind‚Äù by doing ‚Äúthe most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction of standing armies, and for the holding and promotion of peace congresses.‚ÄùAssange argues that ‚ÄúThe political decision of the Norwegian selection committee does not suspend the fiduciary duty of Swedish funds administrators,‚Äù adding that ‚ÄúAny disbursement contradicting this mandate constitutes misappropriation from the endowment. ‚ÄùAssange‚Äôs filing contends that Machado‚Äôs public endorsement of US President Donald Trump and the administration‚Äôs military actions, which the complaint frames as contributing to war crimes, provides sufficient legal grounds for the Nobel Foundation to suspend all financial disbursements linked to the prize. ‚ÄúAlfred Nobel‚Äôs endowment for peace cannot be spent on the promotion of war,‚Äù Assange said, alleging that Machado ‚Äúhas continued to incite the Trump Administration to pursue its escalatory path‚Äù against Venezuela.The complaint also cites precedent within the Nobel system, noting that Nobel Foundation officials exercised supervisory authority by withholding prize-related disbursements in 2018. Assange argues that, having previously intervened to halt payments, Nobel officials were legally obliged to do so again and that failure to intervene in the present case ‚Äúincurs criminal liability‚Äù under Swedish law.The filing explicitly invokes Sweden‚Äôs obligations under Article 25(3)(c) of the Rome Statute, arguing that continued disbursement of Nobel funds, despite knowledge of Machado‚Äôs public positions, could amount to facilitating the crime of aggression, war crimes and crimes against humanity. Assange has asked authorities to seize internal records, including board minutes and financial documents, interrogate senior Nobel officials, and either pursue a domestic investigation or refer the matter to the International Criminal Court.In October, Machado described her Nobel Peace Prize win as an ‚Äúimmense recognition‚Äù of her country‚Äôs struggle for democracy and dedicated the award to US President Donald Trump. In a post on X following the announcement, she wrote: ‚ÄúThis immense recognition of the struggle of all Venezuelans is a boost to complete our task: to conquer Freedom. We are on the threshold of victory and today, more than ever, we have President Trump, the people of the United States, the peoples of Latin America, and the democratic nations of the world as our main allies to achieve Freedom and democracy. Venezuela will be free!‚ÄùSpeaking to reporters in Oslo last week, hours after her daughter accepted the Nobel Peace Prize on her behalf, Machado said: ‚ÄúI think that the actions of President Trump have been decisive‚Ä¶ Now they start to understand that this is serious, and that the world is watching.‚Äù She declined to answer directly whether US military intervention was necessary to oust Maduro.Assange warned that without intervention, the Peace Prize risks being ‚Äúpermanently converted from an instrument of peace into an instrument of war.‚Äù
Article Summary: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has filed a criminal complaint in Sweden accusing senior figures linked to the Nobel Foundation of serious economic crimes. Assange alleges breach of trust, gross misappropriation of funds, conspiracy, and the facilitation of war crimes and crimes against humanity. The complaint follows the award of the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize to Venezuelan opposition leader Mar√≠a Corina Machado.

Article Title: Don‚Äôt lose your H-1B job: US immigration experts advise Indians stuck at home amid visa appointment delays
Article Text:
H-1B Showdown: Amazon, Google Microsoft Pour Billions Into India as 20 States Sue Trump

'Trump administration is more powerful on border'





Immigration attorney Emily Neumann said the first thing that H-1B visa holders who are now stuck at home because all appointments have been delayed by at least six months, owing to the social media vetting, is to keep their H-1B job. The expert said that if a person loses his or her job, they will have to look for another job on an H-1B visa, which will cost the company $100,000 fee, and the companies are unlikely to shell out the fee.If the US employer does not allow work from home for six months, as many appointments in India got deferred by at least six months, the candidates can request an emergency appointment, Neumann said, adding that there is a slimmer chance for that to happen. You are pretty much stuck," Neumann said.Immigration lawyer Rahul Reddy said the social media vetting is just an excuse to cut candidates off. Reddy said that if the Donald Trump administration wants to change something in non-immigrant visa programs, it will take a long time, as it has to go through Congress. But the Trump administration is more powerful at the border, and when a visa holder is outside the country, it can stop anyone from coming in, the expert said, adding that all visa-holders in the US should cancel their travel plans as now is not a good time for it.The State Department stalled all visa appointments to reduce the number of interviews daily in consular offices as social media vetting of all candidates that began from December 15 is taking a longer time now.

"And these big price cuts will greatly reduce the cost of health care. The money should go to the people," he said.

Article Title: The making of Jeffrey Epstein: How a Brooklyn math teacher turned access into fortune
Article Text:

With just hours left before a court-mandated disclosure, Congressional Democrats on Thursday released dozens of new photographs from Jeffrey Epstein ‚Äôs estate, intensifying pressure on the justice department to open its long-sealed files on the late financier and convicted sex offender.Democrats on the House Oversight Committee have released 68 disturbing images from Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs estate, offering a chilling window into his network and alleged crimes. The photos include:‚Ä¢Passages from Lolita inked across a woman‚Äôs body‚Ä¢Redacted IDs of women from seven countries‚Ä¢Late-night texts arranging girls for someone named ‚Äúj‚Äù at $1,000 eachThe images are part of a 95,000-photo archive now in the committee‚Äôs hands.The US justice department faces a December 19 deadline to release its Epstein investigation records under the Epstein Files Transparency Act.‚ÄúWe must end this White House cover-up,‚Äù said Rep. Robert Garcia, the committee‚Äôs top Democrat. ‚ÄúThe DOJ must release the Epstein files now.‚ÄùPhotos also show Epstein alongside major figures including President Donald Trump , Bill Gates, Noam Chomsky, and Steve Bannon. Only the White House has responded, dismissing the release as irrelevant: ‚ÄúThe Trump administration has delivered on transparency,‚Äù said spokesperson Abigail Jackson.The origins of Epstein‚Äôs wealth explain how he was able to operate with impunity for decades. His fortune allowed him to:* Buy access to politicians, scientists, and celebrities.* Acquire properties where abuse occurred.* Fund an international sex-trafficking ring that entrapped hundreds of girls and young women.As Senator Ron Wyden said, ‚ÄúFollowing the money is how, in our country, we‚Äôve had a long history of catching and rooting out corrupt behavior.‚ÄùJeffrey Epstein wasn‚Äôt born into money, didn‚Äôt finish college, and wasn‚Äôt a Wall Street prodigy - but he built a fortune that funded his access to billionaires, presidents, and underage girls. His rise was marked by brazen lies, insider connections, and a knack for manipulating powerful men who repeatedly looked the other way.A New York Times investigation paints the clearest picture yet: Epstein was less a financial genius, more a grifter in a suit - one who gamed the system, rigged deals, and monetized relationships, all while constructing a predatory sex-trafficking network that shocked the world.Epstein story, pieced together through years of reporting by The New York Times and others, reveals something less cinematic than espionage or secret client lists, and more unsettling: a career built on proximity, manipulation, and a near-total absence of consequences.In 1976, Epstein was a 23-year-old math teacher at the Dalton School, a prestigious private school on Manhattan‚Äôs Upper East Side. He was about to be asked to leave. His teaching was undistinguished. His credentials, as it turned out, were fictional.Then he attended an art gallery opening.A Dalton parent introduced Epstein to another parent, who in turn placed a phone call to Ace Greenberg, the legendary Bear Stearns executive. Epstein showed up to the firm‚Äôs offices wearing a turtleneck and knowing almost nothing about Wall Street.Greenberg hired him anyway.Bear Stearns prided itself on recruiting what Greenberg called ‚ÄúP.S.D.s‚Äù - poor, smart, and driven. Epstein fit the mold. He was soon earning a Wall Street salary and dating Greenberg‚Äôs daughter, a relationship that conferred informal protection inside the firm, according to former colleagues interviewed by The New York Times.Within months, Epstein was caught lying about having college degrees. He admitted it calmly. His supervisor confronted him. Nothing happened.It would not be the last time.At Bear Stearns, Epstein learned less about finance than about leverage.According to the Times, he abused expense accounts, charged luxury travel for girlfriends, and improperly allocated ‚Äúhot‚Äù initial public offering shares to people he was sleeping with. He loaned money in ways that violated brokerage rules. He was questioned by the Securities and Exchange Commission during an insider-trading investigation.Each time, Epstein escaped serious punishment.By 1980, he was named a limited partner, pulling in the equivalent of more than $800,000 a year. Cosmopolitan magazine named him ‚ÄúBachelor of the Month,‚Äù describing him as someone who ‚Äútalks only to people who make over a million a year.‚ÄùBear Stearns eventually opened a formal investigation. Epstein resigned before the penalties could land.What he took with him was more valuable than a severance package: credibility.After leaving Bear Stearns, Epstein styled himself as a financial fixer, adviser and, at times, what he called a ‚Äúbounty hunter‚Äù - someone who recovered lost or hidden assets for wealthy families.In practice, the line between consulting and con artistry was thin.A British defense contractor, Douglas Leese, hired Epstein and later accused him of abusing expense accounts. A businessman named Michael Stroll entrusted Epstein with $450,000 - roughly ten percent of his net worth - for a supposed oil deal. Most of the money disappeared. Epstein eventually prevailed in court on technical grounds.‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a despicable prick,‚Äù Stroll later said in an unpublished interview cited by the Times.Again, there were no real consequences.According to reporting by The New York Times, Epstein exaggerated relationships, borrowed prestige from old employers, and continued answering his phone ‚ÄúBear Stearns‚Äù long after leaving the firm. Former colleagues kept introducing him to clients. Doors stayed open.Each small deception funded the next.Epstein‚Äôs first undeniable windfall came not from trading but from recovery.In the early 1980s, the brokerage firm Drysdale Securities collapsed, wiping out millions for wealthy families, including Spanish aristocrats. Epstein, through a girlfriend, was hired to help track down missing funds. Working with a former federal prosecutor, he located money hidden in offshore accounts.The reward made him a millionaire.From there, Epstein moved into larger circles, exaggerating his role with powerful figures, including David Rockefeller - an association the Times later reported Epstein inflated far beyond reality. He cultivated foundations, donated strategically, and used famous names as social currency.By the late 1980s, Epstein had found his most important patron: Leslie Wexner, the billionaire retail magnate behind Victoria‚Äôs Secret. Wexner granted Epstein sweeping control over his finances. That relationship would underwrite Epstein‚Äôs mansions, private jets, and global mobility.It would also insulate him for years.(With inputs from agencies)

Article Title: Can Trump rename the Kennedy Center? Board vote sparks constitutional debate
Article Text: A board handpicked by President Donald Trump voted Thursday to rename the John F. Kennedy Memorial Center for the Performing Arts as the Trump‚ÄìKennedy Center, inserting the sitting president‚Äôs name alongside one of the nation‚Äôs most revered political legacies.Within hours, the centre‚Äôs website reflected the change ‚Äî even as critics warned the board may have raced ahead of the law.Congress named the Kennedy Center in 1964, following President John F. Kennedy‚Äôs assassination, and legal historians say only Congress can formally alter that designation. But Trump, who chairs the board after reshaping it with loyalists since returning to office, welcomed the vote as an ‚Äúhonour,‚Äù saying he was surprised by the decision.But the board did not wait for that debate to play out, immediately changing the branding on its website to reflect the new name.House Democratic leader Hakeem Jeffries told reporters that legislative action was needed, ‚Äúand we‚Äôre going to make that clear.‚Äù The New York Democrat is an ex officio member of the board because of his position in Congress.‚ÄúThe Kennedy Center Board of Trustees voted unanimously today to name the institution the Donald J.Trump and the John F. Kennedy Memorial Center for the Performing Arts,‚Äù said Roma Daravi, the institution‚Äôs public relations vice-president.She said the vote recognised that Trump saved the centre from ‚Äúfinancial ruin and physical destruction,‚Äù a pair of claims denied by the venue‚Äôs ousted leadership. ‚ÄúThe new Trump Kennedy Center reflects the unequivocal bipartisan support for America‚Äôs cultural centre for generations to come,‚Äù Daravi said.White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt announced the vote on social media, attributing it to the ‚Äúunbelievable work‚Äù Trump has done on the centre since he returned to office in January.Trump, a Republican who chairs the board, said at the White House that he was ‚Äúsurprised‚Äù and ‚Äúhonoured‚Äù by the vote. ‚ÄúThe board is a very distinguished board, most distinguished people in the country and I was surprised by it and I was honoured by it,‚Äù he said.Trump had already been referring to the centre as the ‚ÄúTrump Kennedy Center.‚Äù Asked December 7 as he walked the red carpet for the Kennedy Center Honors programme whether he would rename the venue after himself, Trump said such a decision would be up to the board.Earlier this month, Trump talked about a ‚Äúbig event‚Äù happening at the ‚ÄúTrump Kennedy Center‚Äù before saying, ‚Äúexcuse me, at the Kennedy Center,‚Äù as his audience laughed. He was referring to the FIFA World Cup soccer draw for 2026, in which he participated.A name change isn‚Äôt sitting well with some Kennedy family members.JFK family reactsJack Schlossberg, President John F. Kennedy‚Äôs grandson, wrote on X, "Microphones were muted and the board meeting and vote NOT unanimous."The Democrat suggested that Trump was "explicitly motivated to act" due to his New York congressional campaign, adding: "Our campaign represents everything Trump can't stand or defeat."Former Rep. Joe Kennedy III (D-Mass.), grandson of former Attorney General and assassinated presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, posted on his social media accounts: "The Kennedy Center is a living memorial to a fallen president and named for President Kennedy by federal law. It can no sooner be renamed than can someone rename the Lincoln Memorial, no matter what anyone says."
Article Summary: Congress named the Kennedy Center in 1964, following President John F. Kennedy‚Äôs assassination. Legal historians say only Congress can formally alter that designation. Trump, who chairs the board, welcomed the vote as an ‚Äúhonour,‚Äù saying he was surprised by the decision.

Article Title: ‚ÄòFirst casualty of the fusion wars‚Äô: Killing of MIT‚Äôs top nuclear scientist Nuno Loureiro sparks online speculation
Article Text:
Wave of online speculation after the scientist‚Äôs death

Why fusion research draws intense attention

Who was Nuno Loureiro

What police have said so far





The killing of Nuno Loureiro, a leading nuclear fusion scientist and director of MIT ‚Äôs Plasma Science and Fusion Center, has shocked the global scientific community and fuelled a wave of online speculation about possible motives. Loureiro, 47, was shot and killed at his home in Brookline, Massachusetts, on December 15, 2025. Police have confirmed the death as a homicide and say the investigation remains ongoing, with no suspects or motive publicly identified. In the absence of official details, social media has rapidly filled the information vacuum with theories linking his death to the high-stakes global race for fusion energy.Soon after news of Loureiro‚Äôs death emerged, social media platforms were flooded with speculative and often contradictory claims attempting to explain the killing in the absence of official details. Some users framed him as the ‚Äúfirst casualty of the fusion wars,‚Äù arguing that his work on nuclear fusion threatened entrenched energy industries, particularly fossil fuel companies, by accelerating the path toward a cleaner, long-term alternative. Others extended this narrative to include renewable energy sectors, claiming that large-scale fusion could eventually disrupt existing wind and solar investment models.A separate strain of speculation focused on geopolitics. These posts suggested that foreign governments competing in the global race for next-generation energy technologies, including nuclear fusion, may have viewed Loureiro‚Äôs research as strategically significant. In these narratives, fusion was portrayed not just as a scientific goal but as a future source of economic and geopolitical power. Some posts went further by alleging state-level interference or industrial espionage.Other viral posts asserted that Loureiro was close to a major scientific breakthrough that could have rapidly accelerated the commercial viability of fusion energy.Authorities have repeatedly stated that there is no evidence at this stage connecting Loureiro‚Äôs research, industry interests, or geopolitical competition to his killing. Law enforcement officials have not identified a motive, named suspects, or suggested that his professional work played any role in the homicide. As a result, all such theories remain unverified online speculation rather than conclusions supported by facts.Fusion energy is often portrayed as a future solution to climate change and global energy security, offering power without carbon emissions and minimal long-lived radioactive waste. While progress has been significant, experts stress that fusion remains a long-term scientific challenge involving international collaboration across universities, national laboratories and private companies. No single scientist or institution can determine the pace or outcome of fusion development.Loureiro was an internationally respected plasma physicist who spent more than a decade at MIT working on some of the most difficult problems in nuclear fusion. As director of the Plasma Science and Fusion Center, he led research into turbulence and magnetic reconnection in plasmas, key challenges for making fusion reactors stable and efficient. Colleagues widely regarded him as a rare combination of deep theoretical thinker and gifted teacher.Law enforcement officials have confirmed that Loureiro died from a gunshot wound and that the case is being investigated as a homicide. No arrests have been made, and police have not released details about potential suspects or motives. Investigators have urged caution as the inquiry continues and have warned against drawing conclusions without verified evidence.Beyond the speculation, Loureiro‚Äôs death is being mourned as a major loss to science and education. Students and colleagues remember him for his generosity, mentorship and ability to make complex physics accessible. For many young Portuguese scientists, he was a powerful role model who showed that it was possible to rise from familiar classrooms to the forefront of global research.
Article Summary: Nuno Loureiro was a leading nuclear fusion scientist and director of MIT‚Äôs Plasma Science and Fusion Center. He was shot and killed at his home in Brookline, Massachusetts, on December 15, 2025. Police have confirmed the death as a homicide and say the investigation remains ongoing. In the absence of official details, social media has filled the information vacuum with theories linking his death to the high-stakes global race for fusion energy.

A friend to many, but not really a good friend to any.‚ÄùMiller donned Juicy Couture tracksuits, the popular high school girl uniform, others said. Ryan Terrell, the captain of the debate team who coached Miller for a semester described her as ‚Äúa teenage girl from an upper-income family in a wealthy neighbourhood. She kind of talked like that, just without the California accent.‚ÄùMiller also worked as a photo editor for the student newspaper, the Circuit. The entertainment editor of the paper at the time, Emmi Weiner, told the outlet that she is not surprised by Miller's divisive personality as she had form for it even then. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre never surprised when you hear about something bad that Katie Waldman did,‚Äù she said.It seems Miller carried the Regina George persona to college as well. During her days at the University of Florida, she operated like a "henchman" after joining the ruling party in the university's student government, a former student recalled.‚ÄúShe looked down on people she didn‚Äôt agree with,‚Äù said Jordan Ball, a member of the opposition party at the time.In 2012, on the day of the student elections, Miller and a pal were reportedly caught dumping over 250 copies of a student paper with a front-page endorsement for the opposition party.‚ÄúEspecially after stealing the newspapers, she had a reputation, not just with us, but throughout the whole school, of being unethical,‚Äù said Ford Dwyer, a senator for the opposition party.‚ÄúThe sense that everyone got was that they‚Äôd better all be careful or else, because she had information on them, and she better be respected because she had secrets that she might or might not reveal,‚Äù Dwyer recalled.After graduating from the University of Florida, Miller got a master's in public administration from George Washington University. During Trump's first term, she served as his special assistant as well as press secretary to then-Vice President Mike Pence. She also worked as a spokeswoman for the Department of Homeland Security.It was in 2020 that Katie got hitched to Stephen Miller at the Trump Hotel in Washington. While they knew each other through work, they were introduced to each other through friends in 2018.Post her marriage, she also worked as an advisor for Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency. And in August 2025, Miller launched her very own podcast from her living room, The Katie Miller Show, a weekly podcast for conservative women.Whatever intent she may have had with the podcast, it has failed to reach the hearts of the Americans, who think of it as just another MAGA woman trying to find a space to trend. Additionally, with the controversies surrounding her and her past behaviour being revealed, it seems she is in need of a podcast appearance herself.
Article Summary: Katie Miller, 34, is the wife of U.S. Homeland Security Advisor Stephen Miller. She recently went viral for her explosive interview with FBI chief Kash Patel and his country music star girlfriend Alexis Wilkins on her podcast, 'The Katie Miller Podcast' Some of her past classmates seem to be outing her previous Mean Girls personality.

Article Title: First American Pope appoints Bishop Ronald Hicks as New York‚Äôs next archbishop
Article Text:
Bishop Ronald Hicks speaks during a news conference, Thursday, Dec.18, 2025 in New York. (AP Photo/Ryan Murphy)

Nuestros Peque√±os Hermanos

Pope Leo XIV: Inside the Conclave and the Dawn of a New Papacy





Pope Leo XIV has named Bishop Ronald A. Hicks as the next Archbishop of New York, placing one of the United States‚Äô most influential Catholic archdioceses under new leadership at a moment of institutional transition and political strain.Hicks, 58, currently serves as bishop of Joliet, Illinois. He replaces Cardinal Timothy Dolan, who submitted his resignation earlier this year after turning 75, as required under Vatican rules. The appointment, announced in Vatican City on Thursday, is the most significant US posting made so far by Leo, the first American pope.The New York archdiocese serves roughly 2.5 million Catholics across Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island and seven surrounding counties. Hicks inherits leadership as the archdiocese begins implementing a $300 million settlement fund for survivors of clerical sexual abuse, finalised by Dolan shortly before his retirement.Speaking at a news conference following the announcement, Hicks addressed the settlement directly.‚ÄúAs a church, we can never rest in our efforts to prevent abuse, to protect children and to care for survivors,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhile this work is challenging, it‚Äôs difficult, it‚Äôs painful, I hope it will continue to help in the areas of accountability, transparency and healing.‚ÄùThe fund is intended to cover settlements for most, if not all, of the approximately 1,300 outstanding abuse claims against the archdiocese. It will be financed through budget reductions and the sale of church assets.Dolan had delayed stepping aside while the settlement framework was completed. Vatican practice often allows outgoing bishops to remain in place when abuse litigation or governance issues are unresolved.The leadership change also marks a generational shift. Dolan, a high-profile conservative figure, was a dominant public presence in New York and a prominent voice in national Catholic debates. His tenure included close ties to Republican political figures, including Donald Trump, who appointed him to a Religious Liberty Commission and invited him to pray at his inauguration.Hicks arrives with a different profile. Like Leo, he is Chicago-born and has spent significant time working in Latin America. From 2005 to 2010, he served in El Salvador as regional director of, a church-run programme supporting orphaned and abandoned children across Latin America and the Caribbean.He has also publicly aligned with US bishops critical of the Trump administration‚Äôs immigration policies. In November, Hicks endorsed a statement from the US Conference of Catholic Bishops condemning immigration raids, particularly those affecting Chicago.The message, he said at the time, ‚Äúaffirms our solidarity with all our brothers and sisters as it expresses our concerns, opposition, and hopes with clarity and conviction. It is grounded in the church‚Äôs enduring commitment to the Catholic social teaching of human dignity and a call for meaningful immigration reform.‚ÄùHicks acknowledged his shared background with the pope during interviews following Leo‚Äôs election. He said the two men met in person only in 2024, when then-Cardinal Robert Prevost visited one of his parishes in Illinois.‚ÄúWe grew up literally in the same radius, in the same neighbourhood together,‚Äù Hicks told Chicago‚Äôs WGN-TV. ‚ÄúWe played in the same parks, went swimming in the same pools, like the same pizza places.‚ÄùChristopher White, author of, said the similarities matter.‚ÄúHe won‚Äôt be shy, and at the same time he will also bring a seriousness and willingness to learn that‚Äôs likely to help him on a local level,‚Äù White said. ‚ÄúIt will be different from Dolan‚Äôs larger-than-life persona.‚ÄùHicks was ordained a priest in Chicago, later serving as dean of formation at Mundelein Seminary before being appointed vicar general of the Archdiocese of Chicago in 2015 by Cardinal Blase Cupich. He became an auxiliary bishop in 2018 and was named bishop of Joliet by Pope Francis in 2020.His experience includes navigating the fallout from a 2023 Illinois attorney general‚Äôs report documenting decades of clerical abuse across the state. While the report criticised past diocesan leadership, it noted improvements in safeguarding practices during Hicks‚Äôs tenure.Dolan, for his part, welcomed the appointment publicly.‚ÄúI already love him and appreciate him and trust him,‚Äù Dolan said, adding that Hicks was ‚Äúan early Christmas gift‚Äù for the archdiocese.Hicks, standing in St Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral as archbishop-designate, struck a measured note.‚ÄúI accept this appointment with humility and an open heart,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI ask for your support and your prayers.‚ÄùHe now assumes leadership of a church confronting its past, managing financial redress, and redefining its public voice under the first American pope.
Article Summary: Hicks, 58, currently serves as bishop of Joliet, Illinois. He replaces Cardinal Timothy Dolan, who submitted his resignation earlier this year after turning 75, as required under Vatican rules. The New York archdiocese serves roughly 2.5 million Catholics across Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island and seven surrounding counties.

Article Title: Were Greg Biffle, family on board when Cessna C550 jet crashed in North Carolina? Here's what we know so far
Article Text:
Greg Biffle used his helicopter for Helene rescue





The small plane that crashed Thursday while attempting a landing at North Carolina's Statesville Regional Airport was owned by Greg Biffle, a former NASCAR driver who won 19 Cup Series races in his 20-year career. FAA records show that the plane, a Cessna C550 with the tail number N257BW, is registered to an LLC called GB Aviation Leasing. Flight data shows that the plane took off from the Statesville airport before quickly returning for the attempted landing.No information about the pilot or who were on board has been released as of now. But YouTuber Garret Mitchell, also a family friend of Greg Biffle, made a social media post that Greg Biffle, his wife Cristina, daughter Emma and son Ryder were on the plane. "...because they were on their way to spend the afternoon with us. We are devastated. I'm so sorry to share this," he wrote.In a brief press conference after the crash, city and airport officials confirmed that the crash occurred at around 10:15 a.m., and added that the FAA arrived to take over the crash site at around noon. City manager Ron Smith told reporters that the crash response and investigation is part of a "multi-agency response," adding that " We've had city, county state, feds are here ...everybody is here on site at this point. ""Multiple fatalities are being reported, though the exact number of passengers aboard the plane‚Äîwhich has a capacity of 7 to 8‚Äîremains unclear," a news agency reported. A witness from the nearby Lakewood Gold Club said the aircraft was flying way too low before it crashed.Prayers for Greg Biffle poured in on social media while the details about the crash victims and their condition or how many people were there, are yet to be confirmed."Greg is the racing hero who personally piloted hundreds of rescue and supply missions in his helicopter across Western North Carolina following Hurricane Helene," one wrote. "Greg is the NASCAR driver and hero who flew hundreds of rescue missions in Western North Carolina in his helicopter after Hurricane Helene," another wrote."Unconfirmed reports from local media that Greg and his family were on board. PLEASE pray that‚Äôs not the case. Biffle has touched so many lives. The Cessna Citation II had just taken off, a loud noise was heard by those on the ground, and the plane attempted to quickly land again. Heartbreaking," Nick Sortor posted.After Hurricane Helene devastated parts of western North Carolina and nearby regions, Biffle used his personal helicopter to fly into isolated mountain communities that had been cut off by flooding and washed-out roads. He initially flew to help a single stranded family in Banner Elk, then continued doing multiple daily flights for over a week, delivering food, water, medicine, baby formula, diapers, generators and other essentials to people who had no access by road.
Article Summary: Greg Biffle is a former NASCAR driver who won 19 Cup Series races in his 20-year career. He used his personal helicopter to fly into isolated mountain communities that had been cut off by flooding and washed-out roads after Hurricane Helene. The plane took off from the Statesville airport before quickly returning for the attempted landing.

Article Title: Pakistan: Former PM Imran Khan's sisters, supporters booked under anti-terrorism law; 14 arrested
Article Text:
Aleema Khan

‚ÄòMight Never See Him Again‚Äô: Imran Khan‚Äôs Sons Claim 'Psychological Torture' In Pak's Adiala Jail





Pakistan police on Wednesday registered a case under the Anti-Terrorism Act against the sisters of former prime minister Imran Khan and dozens of his supporters after a protest sit-in outside Adiala Jail in Rawalpindi.The protest on Tuesday was held after authorities refused to allow family members and lawyers to meet Khan, who is currently incarcerated. His sisters, along with leaders and workers of the Pakistan Tehreek-i-Insaf (PTI), staged the sit-in outside the jail to protest the restriction.Police said a first information report (FIR) was lodged at Police Station Saddar Beroni, Rawalpindi, naming Khan‚Äôs sisters Aleema Khan and Noreen Niazi, as well as several PTI leaders and supporters. Those named include Salman Akram Raja, Naeem Panjotha, Qasim Khan, Aliya Hamza and Raja Nasir Abbas.Authorities also invoked Section 120 of the Pakistan Penal Code for alleged criminal conspiracy against the state, along with charges of attacking police personnel and violating Section 144.Police said, as reported by PTI, at least 14 suspects were arrested at the scene late Tuesday night, and efforts are continuing to arrest others named in the FIR.Imran Khan has been in jail since August 2023 and faces multiple cases filed after his removal from office in April 2022.Officials have placed restrictions on meetings with Khan, saying such visits are being used for political purposes. The last meeting with him took place on December 2, when his sister Uzma Khan was allowed to see him.
Article Summary: Police register a case against the sisters of former prime minister Imran Khan and dozens of his supporters after a protest sit-in outside Adiala Jail in Rawalpindi. The protest was held after authorities refused to allow family members and lawyers to meet Khan, who is currently incarcerated.

Article Title: Still afloat, still fragile: How Pakistan economy is dodging a complete collapse ‚Äî explained
Article Text:
Quetta, Pakistan (AP file photo)

IMF‚Äôs New Conditions Expose Pakistan‚Äôs Deep Economic Faultlines Amid $7 Billion Rescue Package

(Source: IMF)

What is keeping Pakistan afloat

IMF support: Pakistan's key lifeline

(Source: IMF)

Tactical monetary management

Signs of financial market confidence

Tentative re-engagement with US

Deepening strategic and economic ties with China

The structural weaknesses holding Pakistan back

IMF's diagnosis of 'state capture' and 'elite privilege'

'Diagnosis is familiar, implementation is not'

Transparency concerns in federal structure

World Bank warning: stability without prosperity

India's decision to suspend IWT

(PTI file photo)

Operation Sindoor and security spillovers

Afghanistan's dams ‚Äî a second, converging shock

Survival without transformation





How is Pakistan‚Äôs economy still surviving? The question continues to arise as the country grapples with prolonged economic stress despite years of weak growth and low human development indicators.In recent years, Pakistan has dealt with sharp currency swings, runaways inflation between 2022 and 2024, persistent balance-of-payments pressures and mounting external debt burden. Yet the economy has managed to dodge a complete collapse, largely due to repeated bailouts from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and emergency financing from external partners.China has been key to this survival. Chinese loans and infrastructure investments have provided short-term relief but have also deepened Islamabad's financial dependence on Beijing. At the same time, Pakistan has sought to rebuild ties with the United States, long regarded as a key economic and diplomatic backstop.In this outreach, both army chief Asim Munir, now seen as the Pakistan's de facto power centre, and Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif have taken apparent steps to engage Washington. The two leaders went ahead to nominate US President Donald Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize, citing his role in easing military tensions with India.However, New Delhi had turned down the claims of any foreign influence in peaceful agreement with Islamabad in May this year.And Uncle Sam responded with goodwill. Compared to several other countries, it was exempted from steep trade tariffs, with Washington announcing a lower levy of 19%. Trump has also spoken of possible cooperation in developing what he described as "massive oil reserves" in Pakistan.The power structure in Pakistan has also been a point of concern in its economic turmoil. The military's expanding role in governance has often overshadowed the civilian leadership, while former prime minister and a popular leader Imran Khan remains in prison, keeping political tensions high and weighing on investor confidence.Neighbouring countries have also added to Pakistan‚Äôs economic strain. India‚Äôs suspension of the Indus Waters Treaty has emerged as a major setback, while Afghanistan‚Äôs Taliban government has announced plans to build dams upstream, moves that could further affect water availability and pose another risk to Pakistan‚Äôs economy and GDP growth.For now, Pakistan‚Äôs economy continues to function through foreign assistance, administrative controls and short-term stabilisation measures. Without sustained political stability, meaningful reforms and an effective check on corruption, its economic survival remains fragile.One of the most important stabilisers of Pakistan's economy has been the continued support from the International Monetary Fund and other multilateral lenders.The Governance and Corruption Diagnostic Assessment (GCDA) finalised in November 2025, was released ahead of the Fund's executive board's expected approval of a $1.2 billion disbursement, part of the ongoing 37-month, $7 billion programme started under the prime ministership of Shehbaz Sharif.With the latest approval, Pakistan has received around $3.3 billion from the IMF since last year. Under the bailout programme, Islamabad will continue to receive loan instalments over a 37-month period, contingent on meeting the agreed reform conditions.Pakistan narrowly avoided default in 2023 only after the IMF extended an earlier nine-month emergency deal, which was followed by the current longer programme. Since 1958, Pakistan has turned to the IMF 25 times, making it one of the IMF's most frequent borrowers.In 2025, IMF disbursements helped rebuild foreign exchange buffers, reassure markets and finance imports and debt servicing, according to Reuters.Pakistan's central bank has used monetary policy as a tactical tool to stabilise inflation while cautiously supporting growth.On December 15, the State Bank of Pakistan cut its key interest rate by 50 basis points to 10.5%, breaking a four-meeting hold. The SBP said the move was aimed at supporting sustainable economic growth while keeping inflation within target.According to Reuters, all 12 analysts in a Reuters poll had expected the central bank to hold the policy rate at 11%, particularly after the IMF warned against premature easing under Pakistan's $7 billion loan programme.The rate cut highlighted Pakistan's effort to revive domestic economic activity without destabilising the IMF-backed stabilisation framework.Despite underlying weaknesses, Pakistan has seen improving sentiment in financial markets.Credit ratings agencies S&P Global, Fitch and Moody‚Äôs upgraded Pakistan‚Äôs credit ratings in 2025, citing stronger finances and revenue gains. Investor appetite for Pakistan‚Äôs dollar bonds and equities has strengthened, with bonds delivering nearly 22% returns this year and the benchmark stock index gaining 44%, among the best performers in Asia.Bloomberg Economics estimates growth quickened to 3.4% year-on-year in the second quarter, with official data expected shortly.However, with the backdrop of political chaos, most notably the continued imprisonment of the country's most popular political figure, Imran Khan, investors have little confidence to make long-term plans in Pakistan.Pakistan has also moved to rebuild economic ties with the United States.According to Bloomberg, Islamabad is planning an investor conference in Washington to draw American investment in energy, mining and technology. Finance minister Muhammad Aurangzeb said the sectors where Pakistan seeks US investment are clearly identified.Economic links have improved following a new US-Pakistan trade deal setting a 19% tariff, lower than regional peers and well below the 50% tariff imposed on India.Meanwhile, Trump also promised to help Pakistan develop what he described as "massive oil reserves" on Pakistani soil. The remarks followed sustained praise and outreach from Pakistan‚Äôs de facto power centre, army chief Asim Munir, and were later echoed by Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif, who went on to nominate Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize on several occasions.‚ÄúThe first thing was to get the trade equation out of the way, which it is now,‚Äù Aurangzeb told Bloomberg."Every single industry in Pakistan has to have an export component, because it‚Äôs the only way we're going to get out of this boom-and-bust cycle," Aurangzeb added.Beyond Western partners, Pakistan continues to rely heavily on China.According to the Middle East Institute, Pakistan‚Äôs strategic reliance on Beijing has deepened, particularly through the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). In January, Dawn reported that Pakistan and China reaffirmed their commitment to high-quality development of CPEC 2.0, focusing on industrialisation, special economic zones, clean energy, agriculture and livelihood projects.Chinese support has provided Pakistan with infrastructure investment, energy projects and diplomatic backing at moments of economic stress.While IMF financing has stabilised Pakistan, the IMF's own assessment paints a deeply troubling picture of governance in the Islamic Republic.The IMF's Governance and Corruption Diagnostic Assessment concluded that corruption in Pakistan is driven by "state capture", where public policy is manipulated to benefit a narrow circle of political and business elites.The 186-page report described dysfunctional institutions unable to enforce the rule of law or protect public resources. Corruption, the IMF said, is persistent and corrosive, distorting markets, eroding public trust and undermining fiscal stability.The report warns that without dismantling entrenched structures of elite privilege, Pakistan‚Äôs economic stagnation will persist.According to the IMF, the most economically damaging corruption involves privileged entities that exert influence over key economic sectors, including those owned by or affiliated with the state.Stefan Dercon, a professor of economic policy at the University of Oxford who has advised Pakistan on reforms, told Al Jazeera that lack of accountability continues to erode economic potential."Failure of implementation [of laws and principles of accountability] gives vested interests too often free rein and addressing this must be at the core of efforts for economic reform," Dercon said.Ali Hasanain, associate professor of economics at the Lahore University of Management Sciences, said the IMF‚Äôs findings mirror long-standing domestic research."The IMF diagnostic repeats what many domestic studies, including those by the World Bank and Pakistan‚Äôs own institutions, have already emphasised: Powerful interests shape rules to maintain their advantage," Hasanain told Al Jazeera.A 2021 UNDP report found that economic privileges granted to Pakistan‚Äôs elite, including politicians and the powerful military, amount to roughly 6 percent of GDP.The IMF report also flags governance risks linked to the Special Investment Facilitation Council (SIFC), created in June 2023 to promote investment and comprising both civilian and military leaders.The GCDA raises concerns over broad legal immunity granted to SIFC officials and the council‚Äôs authority to exempt projects from regulatory requirements.‚ÄúThe recently established Special Investment Facilitation Council, which has been vested with substantial authority to facilitate foreign investments, operates with untested transparency and accountability provisions,‚Äù the IMF report said.The Fund urged greater transparency, including annual public reporting on investments facilitated and concessions granted.The World Bank has warned that macroeconomic stabilisation has not translated into meaningful improvements in living standards."Business as usual is not good for the economy," said Mukhtar Ul Hasan, World Bank economist and lead author of a report on Pakistan."Pakistan's growth potential has been declining for decades" due to weak competitiveness, limited reforms and recurring crises, he added.The World Bank projects growth of 3% this year and 3.4% next year, far below what is needed to absorb 1.6 million new labour market entrants annually.The Bank‚Äôs poverty and resilience report shows poverty rising again to over 27% by 2023‚Äì24, with nearly half the population living below the lower-middle-income poverty line. Rural areas, especially Balochistan and interior Sindh, face far greater deprivation.Geopolitics has added new economic risks.After a Pakistan-sponsored terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir‚Äôs Pahalgam that killed 26 civilians, India answered strongly to its misadventure by putting the Indus Waters Treaty in abeyance. Islamabad responded by warning that any attempt to stop or divert water flows would be treated as an "act of war."Around 80% of Pakistani farms depend on the Indus system, as do nearly all hydropower projects. India had also identified hydropower projects in Jammu and Kashmir that could expand capacity to 12,000 MW from the current 3,360 MW, according to Reuters.In May 2025 India‚Äôs crossborder counterterror action under Operation Sindoor, marked a sharp escalation in India-Pakistan security dynamics. Military operations and reciprocal measures elevate defence spending, crowd out development spending, spook investors, and raise insurance and logistics costs for trade.Pakistan suffered a major setback after Indian strikes severely damaged nine of its key airbases, including Nur Khan and Rahim Yar Khan, dealing a significant blow to its military infrastructure.Pakistan‚Äôs economic capacity has been heavily drained by sustained military expenditure driven by its adversarial policies toward India, a burden that has come at the cost of investment in social sectors and has pushed the country down across multiple human development indicators.Reports indicate Afghanistan's new dam projects on rivers that feed Pakistan (Kunar/Kabul tributaries) will further diminish cross-border flows into Pakistan‚Äôs north-west. Combined with India‚Äôs measures, this convergence would be a "double blast" to Pakistani water security ‚Äî concentrated in already drought-prone provinces that supply major agricultural output.Reduced river flows affect irrigation, livelihoods and hydroelectricity; they also fuel internal migration pressures and raise the social cost of adjustment. Regional cooperation mechanisms for water management have weakened, making unilateral upstream development a direct economic shock for downstream Pakistan.Pakistan‚Äôs economy is surviving due to IMF support, tactical policy moves, selective foreign investment and geopolitical manoeuvring, including heavy dependence on China and US.But without deep structural reform, dismantling elite privilege and restoring institutional accountability, survival may continue without delivering broad-based prosperity, leaving the country trapped in the same cycle of crisis and rescue that has defined its economic history.
Article Summary: Pakistan narrowly avoided default in 2023 only after the IMF extended an earlier nine-month emergency deal. Since 1958, Pakistan has turned to the IMF 25 times, making it one of the IMF's most borrowers. Without sustained political stability, meaningful reforms and an effective check on corruption, Pakistan's economic survival remains fragile.

Article Title: Trump, troops and trouble at home: Why Asim Munir's next move could shake Pakistan
Article Text:
Pakistan army chief Asim Munir (AP file photo)

Trump Puts Asim Munir On Gaza Test: Can Pak Army Chief Appease U.S & Avoid Backlash At Home?

'Pressure to deliver'

Munir's unprecedented power

Risks at home





Pakistan's de facto state head and most powerful army chief in decades is facing the toughest test of his expanding stronghold in Islamabad power centre as the United States presses Islamabad to send troops to a Gaza stabilisation force, a move analysts told Reuters could spark strong domestic backlash. It could also "annoy the US president" if Munir shows disinterest in contributing to the peace plan.Military chief Munir, who holds enormous influenceover Pakistan's political and economic decisions, is expected to travel to Washington in the coming weeks to meet US President Donald Trump . It would be their third meeting in six months and is likely to focus on Pakistan's possible role in Gaza, according to two sources familiar with the matter, one of whom is closely involved in Munir‚Äôs economic outreach to the US.Trump's proposed 20-point plan for Gaza calls for troops from Muslim-majority countries to oversee a transition period focused on reconstruction and economic recovery in the Palestinian territory. Gaza has been devastated by more than two years of Israeli military bombardment.Many countries are cautious about joining such a force because it could involve disarming Hamas, Gaza's Islamist militant group. Analysts say this risks pulling foreign troops deeper into the conflict and could inflame pro-Palestinian and anti-Israeli public opinion at home.Munir, however, has developed close ties with Trump as part of an effort to repair years of strained relations between Washington and Islamabad. In June, Trump hosted Munir for a private lunch at the White House ‚Äî the first time a US president met Pakistan‚Äôs army chief alone, without any civilian leaders present."Not contributing (to the Gaza stabilisation force) could annoy Trump, which is no small matter for a Pakistani state that appears quite keen to remain in his good graces - in great part to secure U.S. investment and security aid," said Michael Kugelman, Senior Fellow, South Asia at the Washington-based Atlantic Council.Pakistan is the world's only Muslim-majority country with nuclear weapons and has a powerful, experienced military. It has fought three wars with rival India, a brief conflict earlier this year, and has long battled insurgencies in its remote regions. It is also currently fighting Islamist militants that it says operate from neighbouring Afghanistan.Because of this military capability, expectations are higher for Pakistan to contribute, said defence analyst and author Ayesha Siddiqa.Pakistan‚Äôs military strength means "there is a greater pressure on Munir to deliver his capacity," she said.Pakistan‚Äôs military, foreign office and information ministry did not respond to Reuters‚Äô questions. The White House also did not reply to a request for comment.Foreign Minister Ishaq Dar said last month that Pakistan could consider contributing troops for peacekeeping, but made clear that disarming Hamas was not Islamabad‚Äôs responsibility.Earlier this month, Munir was appointed chief of the defence forces, placing the army, air force and navy under his command. He also received a job extension until 2030.Under constitutional amendments passed by Pakistan‚Äôs civilian government last month, Munir will retain his field marshal rank for life and enjoy lifetime immunity from criminal prosecution."Few people in Pakistan enjoy the luxury of being able to take risks more than Munir. He has unbridled power, now constitutionally protected," Kugelman said.In recent weeks, Munir has met leaders from Indonesia, Malaysia, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Jordan, Egypt and Qatar, according to military statements. Siddiqa said these meetings appear aimed at consulting Muslim countries on the proposed Gaza force.At home, however, the biggest risk is political unrest. Any deployment of Pakistani troops to Gaza under a US-backed plan could revive protests by Islamist parties that strongly oppose the US and Israel.These groups have the ability to bring thousands of supporters onto the streets.In October, authorities banned a powerful and violent Islamist party known for pushing Pakistan‚Äôs strict blasphemy laws. Officials said its leaders were arrested, more than 1,500 supporters detained, and its assets and bank accounts seized. Despite the ban, analysts say the group‚Äôs ideology still has influence.Supporters of jailed former prime minister Imran Khan, whose party won the most seats in the 2024 elections, are also deeply hostile to Munir and could mobilise against him.Abdul Basit, Senior Associate Fellow at Singapore‚Äôs S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies, warned that any escalation after deployment could quickly spiral."People will say 'Asim Munir is doing Israel's bidding' - it will be foolhardy of anyone not to see it coming."
Article Summary: Pakistan's de facto state head and most powerful army chief in decades is facing the toughest test of his expanding stronghold in Islamabad power centre. Asim Munir is expected to travel to Washington in the coming weeks to meet US President Donald Trump. It would be their third meeting in six months.

Article Title: Lahore-Multan bus-trailer collision leaves hostess dead, injures 14
Article Text:
Lahore-Multan bus-trailer collision leaves hostess dead, injures 14





KHANEWAL (PAKISTAN): A bus hostess was killed, and at least 14 passengers were injured on Saturday after a passenger bus collided with a trailer near the Makhdoom Pur Interchange on the M-4 Motorway, triggering a large-scale rescue operation, ARY News reported.According to Rescue 1122 officials, the emergency control room received an alert about a serious crash involving a bus travelling from Lahore to Multan.Rescue teams were immediately dispatched to the scene, where they found several passengers trapped inside the damaged vehicle, according to ARY News.Rescue personnel worked swiftly to evacuate everyone trapped inside the bus. Nine injured passengers were given first aid at the accident site, while five others were found to be in critical condition. The bus hostess died on the spot due to the impact of the collision.Rescue 1122 shifted the dead body and all injured passengers to the Tehsil Headquarters (THQ) Hospital, Kabirwala.A spokesperson for the Motorway Police said preliminary findings indicate the accident was caused by the bus driver's negligence and drowsiness. Authorities have launched a detailed investigation to determine the exact circumstances leading to the crash.In a separate incident earlier this week, a four-year-old child was killed after being run over by a water tanker in the Farid Colony area of Orangi Town. The incident, reported by ARY News, was the third heavy traffic accident recorded in the area on Wednesday.Police said the child, identified as Sufiyan, died on the spot. The accident occurred within the jurisdiction of Momin Abad Police Station in the Faqeer Colony area.The tanker driver fled the scene following the incident, while police took the vehicle into custody and launched a search to trace the driver.Both incidents have once again highlighted concerns over road safety and the growing number of fatal accidents involving heavy vehicles.
Article Summary: Bus travelling from Lahore to Multan collided with trailer on M-4 Motorway. Bus hostess died on the spot due to the impact of the collision. Four-year-old child killed after being run over by water tanker in Orangi Town.

Article Title: Gatecrash or misrepresentation? Did Pakistan PM Shehbaz Sharif interrupt Putin's closed-door meeting? Fact check
Article Text:
Putin Keeps Sharif Waiting In Ashgabat, Desperate Pakistan PM Gate-Crashes Meeting With Erdogan





Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif faced heavy trolling on social media after a video claiming he had "gatecrashed" a closed-door meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan went viral on Friday. The video was later deleted, claiming that it may have been a "misrepresentation of the events".According to a post earlier shared by RT India, Sharif had waited for around 40 minutes for a meeting with President Putin at the International Forum for Peace and Trust in Ashgabat, Turkmenistan.The post claimed that the Pakistani PM then walked into an ongoing meeting between Putin and Erdogan and stayed for about 10 minutes before leaving without securing a separate interaction."PM Sharif waited for over 40 minutes for President Putin before growing tired and gate-crashing the Russian leader's meeting with Erdogan. He left ten minutes later," RT India had earlier posted on X.The video triggered widespread ridicule online, with many users questioning Sharif‚Äôs diplomatic conduct and calling the episode a "huge international embarrassment !!", especially at a time when Pakistan has been trying to strengthen ties with Russia.RT India later deleted the post and issued a clarification, stating that, "We deleted an earlier post about Pakistani Prime Minister Sharif waiting to meet Vladimir Putin at the Peace and Trust Forum in Turkmenistan. The post may have been a misrepresentation of the events."Russian state-owned news agency RIA Novosti reported that Putin and Erdogan continued their talks privately after members of both delegations had exited the room, but made no mention of any alleged "gatecrashing" by Sharif.Meanwhile, Sharif shared a post on X highlighting his interaction with Turkish President Erdogan at the event. "Met my dear brother, President @RTErdogan, on the sidelines of the International Forum on Peace and Trust in Ashgabat. It is always a pleasure to exchange views with a time-tested and trusted friend of Pakistan," Sharif wrote on X.He added that the two leaders reaffirmed "the deep, historic bonds between Pakistan and Turkiye" and discussed cooperation in "trade, energy, defence, connectivity, and investment," along with regional and global issues including Gaza and Afghanistan.The International Forum for Peace and Trust in Ashgabat saw participation from several world leaders, including Putin, Erdogan and Sharif, amid ongoing geopolitical discussions and diplomatic engagements.
Article Summary: Pakistan Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif faced heavy trolling on social media after a video claiming he had "gatecrashed" a closed-door meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan went viral. The video was later deleted, claiming that it may have been a "misrepresentation of the events"

Officials said explosives were planted at the building in Ayaz Kot, leaving more than 600 children without a place to study.Much of the structure was reduced to rubble, prompting authorities to seal the site and begin planning temporary arrangements for classes.Parents and elders condemned the destruction as a deliberate assault on the community‚Äôs future. One elder said the school had been ‚Äúthe heart of our community‚Äù, describing its loss as an attack on children‚Äôs hopes, Express Tribune reported.Security forces have launched a search operation, though no group has claimed responsibility. District officials called the bombing an ‚Äúanti-education act‚Äù and promised those responsible would be brought to justice. Initial assessments suggest the explosives were detonated remotely or with a timer.

Cross-border sanctuaries and international gray zones complicate decisive action.
